clinical_study.official_title: Nutritional Intake, Metabolic Abnormalities and Gut Microbiome in Children

lead_sponsor.agency: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital

clinical_study.source: Hallym University Kangnam Sacred Heart Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Pediatric obesity has been increasing in prevalence, but concerns have been raised around the world because no treatment has been found. Recently, however, research on gut microbiome has begun to become a new alternative. It has been shown that changes in the microbiome in adults may induce obesity. However, the results on children are still scarce. Unlike adults, children have few external factors such as alcohol, tobacco, stress, and cancer, making them suitable for obesity-related gut microbiome studies. The investigators will use Illumina MiSeq platform for 16s rRNA metagenomics profiling in children. In this study, the investigators aimed to analyze the relationship between pediatric obesity, gut microbiome profile, blood biomarkers relevant to metabolic syndrome, and nutrient intake data.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation of fecal microbial profile with childhood obesity
primary_outcome.description: Analysis of fecal microbial profile using 16s rRNA sequencing

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation of fecal microbial profile with nutrient intake data using feeding diary
primary_outcome.description: Nutritional intake analysis of total calorie, carbohydrate, fiber, fat, and protein from feeding dairy for two days

secondary_outcome.measure: Correlation of childhood obesity with metabolic abnomalities using blood sampling
secondary_outcome.description: Glucose, AST, ALT, uric acid, triglyceride, HDL-cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, total cholesterol, insulin, hsCRP, 25(OH)-Vitamin D3, hemoglobin, ferritin, and HbA1c

arm_group.description: 5‰< BMI <85 ‰ for children between the ages of 7 and 12 years

intervention.description: Gut microbial profiling will be done with next-generation sequencing targeting bacterial 16s rRNA genes.

study_pop.textblock: Primary care clinic and community samples

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Obese children: Children ≥95 ‰ between age 7 and 12 years
- Non-obese children: 5‰<BMI <85 ‰ for children between the ages of 7 and 12 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Taking antibiotics, probiotics, or steroids for a month before visit
- Taking probiotics-like products including yogurt for seven days before visit
- Having enteritis symptoms including diarrhea for a month before visit
- Chronic heart disease, chronic bowel disease, chronic liver disease, chronic kidney disease, endocrine disease, genetic diseases or congenital metabolic disorder
